Bernstein Polynomials and nnn-Copulas

M. D. Taylor Department of Mathematics
University of Central Florida
Orlando, FL 32816-1364 mtaylor@pegasus.cc.ucf.edu
May 25, 2014
Abstract.

We give derivations of some basic results for the Bernstein approximation in nnn variables that are useful in investigating copulas. It is shown that Bernstein approximations of copulas are again copulas. We exhibit a stochastic interpretation for the Bernstein approximation of a copula.

Key words and phrases:
Copulas, Bernstein polynomials
2000 Mathematics Subject Classification:
Primary: 60E05; Secondary: 62E17 62H99

1. Introduction

Bernstein approximations of 2-copulas were introduced and studied in [3] and [4]. We assume the reader is familiar with copulas; see, for example, [7] or [6].

This note was written to clarify for myself and my colleagues certain properties of Bernstein approximations that are useful in investigating copulas. We derive some of the basic properties of the Bernstein approximation for functions of nnn variables and then show that the Bernstein approximation of a copula is again a copula. Our most significant result is a stochastic interpretation of the Bernstein approximation of a copula. This interpretation was communicated to us by J. H. B. Kemperman in [2] for 2-copulas and we are not aware of its publication elsewhere.

The encouragement and contributions of our colleagues P. Mikusiński and X. Li to this note were crucial.

2. Bernstein polynomials and approximations

It is our convention that I=[0,1]I01I=[0,1].

Definition 1.

The mmm-th degree Bernstein polynomial bi,m:I→ℝnormal-:subscriptbimnormal-→Iℝb_{i,m}:I\to\mathbb{R} is given by

bi,m⁢(t)=(mi)⁢ti⁢(1-t)m-i,subscriptbimtbinomialmisuperscripttisuperscript1tmib_{i,m}(t)=\binom{m}{i}\,t^{i}(1-t)^{m-i},

i=0,1,…,mi01normal-…mi=0,1,\ldots,m. We extend this to Bi,mn:In→ℝnormal-:subscriptsuperscriptBnimnormal-→superscriptInℝB^{n}_{i,m}:I^{n}\to\mathbb{R} by taking iii to be a multi-index, i=(i1,…,in)isubscripti1normal-…subscriptini=(i_{1},\ldots,i_{n}), where each ik∈{0,1,…,m}subscriptik01normal-…mi_{k}\in\{0,1,\ldots,m\} and setting

Bi,mn⁢(x)=bi1,m⁢(x1)⁢bi2,m⁢(x2)⁢⋯⁢bin,m⁢(xn)subscriptsuperscriptBnimxsubscriptbsubscripti1msubscriptx1subscriptbsubscripti2msubscriptx2normal-⋯subscriptbsubscriptinmsubscriptxnB^{n}_{i,m}(x)=b_{i_{1},m}(x_{1})\,b_{i_{2},m}(x_{2})\cdots b_{i_{n},m}(x_{n})

where x=(x1,…,xn)∈Inxsubscriptx1normal-…subscriptxnsuperscriptInx=(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n})\in I^{n}.

Notice that {Bi,mn}subscriptsuperscriptBnim\{B^{n}_{i,m}\} is a partition of unity over InsuperscriptInI^{n}.

Here is the intuition behind the Bernstein polynomial: Consider the act of tossing a coin mmm times with probability of heads on each toss being xxx. This scenario can be represented by a random vector X:Ω→{0,1}mnormal-:Xnormal-→normal-Ωsuperscript01mX:\Omega\to\{0,1\}^{m} with the property that if X⁢(ω)=(x1,…,xm)Xωsubscriptx1normal-…subscriptxmX(\omega)=(x_{1},\ldots,x_{m}), then P(xi=1)=xfragmentsPfragmentsnormal-(subscriptxi1normal-)xP(x_{i}=1)=x. We then introduce the random variable YYY defined by

Y⁢(ω)=∑{xi: xi=1},Yωconditional-setsubscriptxisubscriptxi1Y(\omega)=\sum\{x_{i}\,:\,x_{i}=1\},

in other words, the number of heads that were tossed. This is familiarly described as a binomially distributed random variable with parameters mmm and xxx. It is easily shown that

E⁢(Y)=m⁢x and V⁢a⁢r⁢(Y)=E⁢((Y-E⁢(Y))2)=m⁢x⁢(1-x).formulae-sequenceEYmxandVarYEsuperscriptYEY2mx1xE(Y)=mx\quad\text{and}\quad Var(Y)=E((Y-E(Y))^{2})=mx(1-x).

Notice that

bi,m(x)=P(Y=i).fragmentssubscriptbimfragmentsnormal-(xnormal-)Pfragmentsnormal-(Yinormal-)normal-.b_{i,m}(x)=P(Y=i).
Definition 2.

If f:In→ℝnormal-:fnormal-→superscriptInℝf:I^{n}\to\mathbb{R}, we define the Bernstein approximation to fff to be

ℬmn⁢(f)=∑if⁢(im)⁢Bi,mnsubscriptsuperscriptℬnmfsubscriptifimsubscriptsuperscriptBnim\mathscr{B}^{n}_{m}(f)=\sum_{i}f(\tfrac{i}{m})\,B^{n}_{i,m}

where iii ranges over all multi-indices i=(i1,…,in)isubscripti1normal-…subscriptini=(i_{1},\ldots,i_{n}) such that each ik∈{0,1,…,m}subscriptik01normal-…mi_{k}\in\{0,1,\ldots,m\}, and by imim\frac{i}{m} we mean the vector (i1m,…,inm)subscripti1mnormal-…subscriptinm\left(\frac{i_{1}}{m},\ldots,\frac{i_{n}}{m}\right).

It can be shown by induction that

∫InBi,mn⁢d⁢λn=1(m+1)nsubscriptsuperscriptInsubscriptsuperscriptBnimdsuperscriptλn1superscriptm1n\int_{I^{n}}B^{n}_{i,m}\,d\lambda^{n}=\frac{1}{(m+1)^{n}}

where λnsuperscriptλn\lambda^{n} is Lebesgue measure on ℝnsuperscriptℝn\mathbb{R}^{n}.

3. The Weierstrass approximation theorem via Bernstein polynomials

Theorem 1.

If f:In→ℝnormal-:fnormal-→superscriptInℝf:I^{n}\to\mathbb{R} is continuous, then ℬmn⁢(f)→fnormal-→subscriptsuperscriptℬnmff\mathscr{B}^{n}_{m}(f)\to f uniformly on InsuperscriptInI^{n} as m→∞normal-→mm\to\infty.

Set fm=ℬmn⁢(f)subscriptfmsuperscriptsubscriptℬmnff_{m}=\mathscr{B}_{m}^{n}(f). We suppose that mmm is so large that 14⁢m⁢δ2<ϵ14msuperscriptδ2ϵ\frac{1}{4m\delta^{2}}<\epsilon; we shall show that this makes |fm-f|subscriptfmf|f_{m}-f| ‘‘small.’’ Choose x=(x1,…,xn)∈Inxsubscriptx1normal-…subscriptxnsuperscriptInx=(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n})\in I^{n}. Then

|fm⁢(x)-f⁢(x)|≤∑d⁢(im,x)<δ⁢|f⁢(im)-f⁢(x)|⁢Bi,mn⁢(x)+∑d⁢(im,x)≥δ⁢|f⁢(im)-f⁢(x)|⁢Bi,mn⁢(x)subscriptfmxfxdFENCEDimxδfimfxsubscriptsuperscriptBnimxdFENCEDimxδfimfxsubscriptsuperscriptBnimx|f_{m}(x)-f(x)|\leq\underset{d\left(\frac{i}{m},x\right)<\delta}{\sum}|f(% \tfrac{i}{m})-f(x)|\,B^{n}_{i,m}(x)+\underset{d\left(\frac{i}{m},x\right)\geq% \delta}{\sum}|f(\tfrac{i}{m})-f(x)|\,B^{n}_{i,m}(x)

4. Derivatives of Bernstein approximations

4.1. Derivatives of Bernstein polynomials

If f:In→ℝnormal-:fnormal-→superscriptInℝf:I^{n}\to\mathbb{R}, set

(1) fm=ℬmn⁢(f)=∑if⁢(im)⁢Bi,mn=∑if⁢(im)⁢bi1,m⊗⋯⊗bin,msubscriptfmsuperscriptsubscriptℬmnfsubscriptifimsuperscriptsubscriptBimnsubscriptitensor-productfimsubscriptbsubscripti1mnormal-⋯subscriptbsubscriptinmf_{m}=\mathscr{B}_{m}^{n}(f)=\sum_{i}f\left(\tfrac{i}{m}\right)\,B_{i,m}^{n}=% \sum_{i}f\left(\tfrac{i}{m}\right)\,b_{i_{1},m}\otimes\cdots\otimes b_{i_{n},m}

where i=(i1,…,in)isubscripti1normal-…subscriptini=(i_{1},\ldots,i_{n}) and ik=0,1,…,msubscriptik01normal-…mi_{k}=0,1,\ldots,m and the symbolism g⊗htensor-productghg\otimes h is interpreted to mean (g⊗h)⁢(u,v)=g⁢(u)⁢h⁢(v)tensor-productghuvguhv(g\otimes h)(u,v)=g(u)\,h(v). We want to compute partial derivatives of fmsubscriptfmf_{m}. In particular we want compute the mixed partial ∂n⁡fm∂⁡x1⁢⋯⁢∂⁡xnsuperscriptnsubscriptfmsubscriptx1normal-⋯subscriptxn\frac{\partial^{n}f_{m}}{\partial x_{1}\cdots\partial x_{n}} which we denote ∂⁡fmsubscriptfm\partial f_{m}. In the case where fmsubscriptfmf_{m} is a cumulative probability distribution function, ∂⁡fmsubscriptfm\partial f_{m} is the associated probability density.

It is convenient at this point to introduce another notation. Let g:A→ℝnormal-:gnormal-→Aℝg:A\to\mathbb{R} where A⊆ℝnAsuperscriptℝnA\subseteq\mathbb{R}^{n}. Suppose v∈ℝnvsuperscriptℝnv\in\mathbb{R}^{n} such that A∩(A-v)≠∅AAvA\cap(A-v)\neq\emptyset. We then define a function Δv⁢g:A∩(A-v)→ℝnormal-:subscriptnormal-Δvgnormal-→AAvℝ\Delta_{v}g:A\cap(A-v)\to\mathbb{R} by Δv⁢g⁢(p)=g⁢(p+v)-g⁢(p)subscriptnormal-Δvgpgpvgp\Delta_{v}g(p)=g(p+v)-g(p). That is, Δv⁢g⁢(p)subscriptnormal-Δvgp\Delta_{v}g(p) is the variation of ggg starting at ppp in the direction vvv. Next, let e1,…,ensubscripte1normal-…subscriptene_{1},\ldots,e_{n} be the standard orthonormal basis for ℝnsuperscriptℝn\mathbb{R}^{n}, that is, e1=(1,0,…,0)subscripte110normal-…0e_{1}=(1,0,\ldots,0), e2=(0,1,0,…,0)subscripte2010normal-…0e_{2}=(0,1,0,\ldots,0), etc. For f:In→ℝnormal-:fnormal-→superscriptInℝf:I^{n}\to\mathbb{R} and i=(i1,…,in)isubscripti1normal-…subscriptini=(i_{1},\ldots,i_{n}), where ik=0,1,…,m-1subscriptik01normal-…m1i_{k}=0,1,\ldots,m-1, we define

Δi,mn⁢f=Δ1m⁢e1⁢Δ1m⁢e2⁢⋯⁢Δ1m⁢en⁢f⁢(im).subscriptsuperscriptnormal-Δnimfsubscriptnormal-Δ1msubscripte1subscriptnormal-Δ1msubscripte2normal-⋯subscriptnormal-Δ1msubscriptenfim\Delta^{n}_{i,m}f=\Delta_{\frac{1}{m}e_{1}}\Delta_{\frac{1}{m}e_{2}}\cdots% \Delta_{\frac{1}{m}e_{n}}f\left(\tfrac{i}{m}\right).

We can think of Δi,mn⁢fsubscriptsuperscriptnormal-Δnimf\Delta^{n}_{i,m}f as the variation of fff over the nnn-dimensional square [i1m,i1+1m)×⋯×[inm,in+1m)subscripti1msubscripti11mnormal-⋯subscriptinmsubscriptin1m\left[\tfrac{i_{1}}{m},\tfrac{i_{1}+1}{m}\right)\times\cdots\times\left[\tfrac% {i_{n}}{m},\tfrac{i_{n}+1}{m}\right).

Returning to the problem of derivatives, one calculates

bi,m′={-m⁢b0,m-1,i=0,m⁢(bi-1,m-1-bi,m-1),0<i<m,m⁢bm-1,m-1,i=m.superscriptsubscriptbimnormal-′-⁢mb0-m1=i0⁢m-b-i1-m1bi-m10<i<m⁢mb-m1-m1=imb_{i,m}^{\prime}=\begin{cases}-m\,b_{0,m-1},&i=0,\\ m\,(b_{i-1,m-1}-b_{i,m-1}),&0<i<m,\\ m\,b_{m-1,m-1},&i=m.\end{cases}

If we set b-1,m-1=bm,m-1=0subscriptb1m1subscriptbmm10b_{-1,m-1}=b_{m,m-1}=0, then we may reduce this to

(2) bi,m′=m⁢(bi-1,m-1-bi,m-1), 0≤i≤m.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptbimnormal-′msubscriptbi1m1subscriptbim10imb_{i,m}^{\prime}=m\,(b_{i-1,m-1}-b_{i,m-1}),\quad 0\leq i\leq m.

If one then considers the case where n=1n1n=1 so that

fm=∑i=0mf⁢(im)⁢bi,m,subscriptfmsuperscriptsubscripti0mfimsubscriptbimf_{m}=\sum_{i=0}^{m}f\left(\tfrac{i}{m}\right)\,b_{i,m},

where iii is now an integer, then one easily calculates

(3) fm′=m⁢∑j=0m-1(Δ1m⁢e1⁢f⁢(jm))⁢bj,m-1.superscriptsubscriptfmnormal-′msuperscriptsubscriptj0m1subscriptnormal-Δ1msubscripte1fjmsubscriptbjm1f_{m}^{\prime}=m\,\sum_{j=0}^{m-1}\left(\Delta_{\frac{1}{m}e_{1}}\,f\left(% \tfrac{j}{m}\right)\right)\,b_{j,m-1}.

We then pass to the general nnn-dimensional case where fmsubscriptfmf_{m} has the form given in (1) and by repeatedly invoking the 1-dimensional case and Equation (3), we obtain

∂⁡fm=mn⁢∑j(Δj,mn⁢f)⁢bj1,m-1⊗⋯⊗bjn,m-1subscriptfmsuperscriptmnsubscriptjtensor-productsubscriptsuperscriptnormal-Δnjmfsubscriptbsubscriptj1m1normal-⋯subscriptbsubscriptjnm1\partial f_{m}=m^{n}\,\sum_{j}\left(\Delta^{n}_{j,m}f\right)\,b_{j_{1},m-1}% \otimes\cdots\otimes b_{j_{n},m-1}

where j=(j1,…,jn)jsubscriptj1normal-…subscriptjnj=(j_{1},\ldots,j_{n}) and jk=0,1,…,m-1subscriptjk01normal-…m1j_{k}=0,1,\ldots,m-1.

It is well-known that the Bernstein approximation of a copula is again a copula (see, for example, [3] and [4]), but this is also an immediate consequence of this last formula:

Theorem 2.

The Bernstein approximation of an nnn-copula is again an nnn-copula.

Proof.

Let Cm=ℬmn⁢(C)subscriptCmsubscriptsuperscriptℬnmCC_{m}=\mathscr{B}^{n}_{m}(C) where CCC is an nnn-copula. The boundary conditions for a copula are easily checked. The only questionable condition is whether or not CmsubscriptCmC_{m} is nnn-increasing. But this follows from the fact that the terms of

∂⁡Cm=mn⁢∑j(Δj,mn⁢C)⁢bj1,m-1⊗⋯⊗bjn,m-1subscriptCmsuperscriptmnsubscriptjtensor-productsubscriptsuperscriptnormal-ΔnjmCsubscriptbsubscriptj1m1normal-⋯subscriptbsubscriptjnm1\partial C_{m}=m^{n}\,\sum_{j}\left(\Delta^{n}_{j,m}C\right)\,b_{j_{1},m-1}% \otimes\cdots\otimes b_{j_{n},m-1}

are nonnegative. ∎

4.2. Some identities and estimates

In what follows, we assume that x∈IxIx\in I, m=1,2,3,…m123normal-…m=1,2,3,\ldots, and i=0,1,…,mi01normal-…mi=0,1,\ldots,m.

The following is straightforward to establish by induction over iii:

Proposition 1.
(im-x)⁢bi,m⁢(x)=x⁢(1-x)⁢(bi-1,m-1⁢(x)-bi,m-1⁢(x)).imxsubscriptbimxx1xsubscriptbi1m1xsubscriptbim1x\left(\frac{i}{m}-x\right)\,b_{i,m}(x)=x\,(1-x)\,(b_{i-1,m-1}(x)-b_{i,m-1}(x)).

∑i=0m|x-im|⁢|bi-1,m-1⁢(x)-bi,m-1⁢(x)|=1m.superscriptsubscripti0mximsubscriptbi1m1xsubscriptbim1x1m\sum_{i=0}^{m}\left|x-\frac{i}{m}\right|\,|b_{i-1,m-1}(x)-b_{i,m-1}(x)|=\frac{% 1}{m}.
Proof.

We assume that XXX is a binomially distributed random variable with parameters xxx and mmm and make use of Proposition 1:

∑i=0m|x-in|⁢|bi-1,m-1⁢(x)-bi,m-1⁢(x)|=1x⁢(1-x)⁢∑i=0m(x-im)2⁢bi,m⁢(x)superscriptsubscripti0mxinsubscriptbi1m1xsubscriptbim1x1x1xsuperscriptsubscripti0msuperscriptxim2subscriptbimx\displaystyle\sum_{i=0}^{m}\left|x-\frac{i}{n}\right|\,|b_{i-1,m-1}(x)-b_{i,m-% 1}(x)|=\frac{1}{x(1-x)}\,\sum_{i=0}^{m}\left(x-\frac{i}{m}\right)^{2}\,b_{i,m}% (x)
=1x⁢(1-x)1m2Var(X)=1m.fragments1x1x1superscriptm2Varfragmentsnormal-(Xnormal-)1mnormal-.\displaystyle=\frac{1}{x(1-x)}\,\frac{1}{m^{2}}\,Var(X)=\frac{1}{m}.

∎

Proposition 3.
∑i=0m|im-x|⁢bi,m⁢(x)=2⁢x⁢(1-x)⁢bi0,m-1⁢(x)superscriptsubscripti0mimxsubscriptbimx2x1xsubscriptbsubscripti0m1x\sum_{i=0}^{m}\left|\frac{i}{m}-x\right|\,b_{i,m}(x)=2\,x\,(1-x)\,b_{i_{0},m-1% }(x)

where i0=⌊m⁢x⌋subscripti0mxi_{0}=\lfloor mx\rfloor, the greatest integer less than or equal to m⁢xmxmx.

Let us assume xxx is irrational, 0<x<10x10<x<1. There is a unique nonnegative integer, namely i0=⌊m⁢x⌋subscripti0mxi_{0}=\lfloor mx\rfloor, such that

i0m<x<i0+1m.subscripti0mxsubscripti01m\frac{i_{0}}{m}<x<\frac{i_{0}+1}{m}.

∑i=0m|im-x|⁢bi,m⁢(x)=∑i=0i0(x-im)⁢bi,m⁢(x)+∑i=i0+1m(im-x)⁢bi,m⁢(x)superscriptsubscripti0mimxsubscriptbimxsuperscriptsubscripti0subscripti0ximsubscriptbimxsuperscriptsubscriptisubscripti01mimxsubscriptbimx\displaystyle\sum_{i=0}^{m}\left|\frac{i}{m}-x\right|\,b_{i,m}(x)=\sum_{i=0}^{% i_{0}}\left(x-\frac{i}{m}\right)\,b_{i,m}(x)+\sum_{i=i_{0}+1}^{m}\left(\frac{i% }{m}-x\right)\,b_{i,m}(x)

A proof of the following has been shown to us informally by our colleague Xin Li, but it can also be found on p. 15 of [5].

Proposition 4.

From [1, p. 304], we find that for each δ>0δ0\delta>0 and s=1,2,…s12normal-…s=1,2,\ldots, there exists C=C⁢(δ,s)CCδsC=C(\delta,s) such that

for m=1,2,…m12normal-…m=1,2,\ldots and x∈IxIx\in I. ∎

4.3. Convergence of first derivatives of Bernstein approximations

Theorem 3.

Suppose that f:In→ℝnormal-:fnormal-→superscriptInℝf:I^{n}\to\mathbb{R} is a bounded function. Then for all x=(x1,…,xn)∈(0,1)nxsubscriptx1normal-…subscriptxnsuperscript01nx=(x_{1},\ldots,x_{n})\in(0,1)^{n} at which fff is differentiable and for k=1,…,nk1normal-…nk=1,\ldots,n, we have

limm→∞⁢∂⁡ℬmn⁢(f)∂⁡xk⁢(x)=∂⁡f∂⁡xk⁢(x).normal-→msuperscriptsubscriptℬmnfsubscriptxkxfsubscriptxkx\underset{m\to\infty}{\lim}\frac{\partial\mathscr{B}_{m}^{n}(f)}{\partial x_{k% }}(x)=\frac{\partial f}{\partial x_{k}}(x).
Proof.

5. A probabilistic interpretation of the Bernstein approximation of a copula

It is our goal here to construct random variables such that the Bernstein approximation is the cumulative distribution function of these new random variables. This probabilistic interpretation was brought to our attention by J. H. B. Kemperman in [2].

Let CCC be an nnn-copula. Suppose it is the cumulative distribution function of the ordered nnn-tuple of random variables (X1,…,Xn)subscriptX1normal-…subscriptXn(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}) where each XisubscriptXiX_{i} is uniformly distributed over III. Let mmm be a ‘‘large’’ natural number and CmsubscriptCmC_{m} be the m×⋯×mmnormal-⋯mm\times\cdots\times m Bernstein approximation of CCC; that is

where x1,…,xn∈Isubscriptx1normal-…subscriptxnIx_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\in I.
